<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics';
	}
</script>

	<title>Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz</title>
	<meta name="description" content="Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more. Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more." />

	<meta property="og:title" content="Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more. Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more." />

webData.published_time = "2024-09-24T14:00:32-07:00";
webData.description = "%%excerpt%% Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more.";

<meta property="og:likes" content="0"/>
<meta property="og:readtime" content="10"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="6,316"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="September 24, 2024 at 2:00 PM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="2504"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Business Email Compromise"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/business-email-compromise/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Shehroze Farooqi"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Howard Tong"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Alex Starov"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="PhaaS,phishing,phishing as a service,Phishing Kit,Proxy Server,Sniper Dz,Telegram"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz","name":"Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz","description":"Delve into the infrastructure and tactics of phishing platform Sniper Dz, which targets popular brands and social media. We discuss its unique aspects and more.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics\/","datePublished":"September 24, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nWe have been monitoring a widely popular phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform named Sniper Dz that primarily targets popular social media platforms and online services. A large number of phishers could be using this platform to launch phishing attacks, since the group behind this kit has thousands of subscribers on its Telegram channel. Our research revealed over 140,000 phishing websites associated with the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform over the past year.\r\n\r\nFor prospective phishers, Sniper Dz offers an online admin panel with a catalog of phishing pages. Phishers can either host these phishing pages on Sniper Dz-owned infrastructure or download Sniper Dz phishing templates to host on their own servers. Surprisingly, Sniper Dz PhaaS offers these services free of charge to phishers \u2013 perhaps because Sniper Dz also collects victim credentials stolen by phishers who use the platform to compensate for the cost of service.\r\n\r\nSniper Dz uses a unique approach of hiding phishing content behind a public proxy server to launch live phishing attacks. The criminals behind this platform auto-setup the proxy server to load phishing content that is hosted on their server. We believe this approach could be useful in protecting their infrastructure from detection.\r\n\r\nCriminals using Sniper Dz often abuse legitimate software-as-a-service (SaaS) platforms to host phishing websites. When establishing their infrastructure, these phishers include popular brand names, trends and even sensitive topics as keywords to lure victims into opening and using their phishing pages. After stealing credentials from a victim, this infrastructure can redirect the victim to malicious advertisements including distribution of potentially unwanted applications or programs (PUA or PUP) like rogue browser installers.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through our Next-Generation Firewall's Advanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security subscriptions.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nPhishing Kit, Business Email Compromise (BEC)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSniper Dz PhaaS Platform\r\nSniper Dz is a PhaaS platform that allows prospective phishers to launch phishing attacks. Sniper Dz offers an admin panel to generate phishing pages.\r\n\r\nGaining access to this admin panel requires creating an account with an email address. Once users (or phishers) create an account, they can access a wide variety of phishing pages targeting popular brands.\r\n\r\nSniper Dz provides two different methods to launch live phishing attacks.\r\n\r\n \tPhishing pages hosted on Sniper Dz infrastructure\r\n \tDownloadable phishing templates to host on one's own infrastructure\r\n\r\nPhishing Pages Hosted on Sniper Dz Infrastructure\r\nSniper Dz can host phishing pages on its own infrastructure and provide customized links pointed to those pages. Figure 1 shows the Sniper Dz admin panel page that shares temporary links pointing to live phishing pages for different brands customized for the registered user. In this way, a prospective phisher does not have to set up a web server to host phishing websites and use Sniper Dz\u2019s infrastructure to launch phishing attacks.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136853\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Sniper Dz admin panel to launch phishing attacks on Sniper Dz-hosted infrastructure.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nContent for these live phishing pages is hidden behind proxy servers to prevent detection, which we will explain in more detail later in this article.\r\nDownloadable Phishing Templates\r\nSniper Dz also enables phishers to download phishing page templates offline as HTML files and host them on their own servers. Figure 2 shows the page to download phishing templates of numerous target brands.\u00a0 Prospective phishers can simply pick a target brand, download the associated phishing page, and deploy it on their own servers.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136855\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. List of downloadable phishing template pages from the Sniper Dz site.[\/caption]\r\nIs This Really a Free-of-Charge PhaaS Platform?\r\nSurprisingly, Sniper Dz offers both phishing attack options free of charge. Normally, PhaaS platforms and phishing kit authors charge money. Setting up a live phishing attack using PhaaS platforms can cost hundreds of dollars in monthly subscription fees, as seen with the Caffeine PhaaS or the Darcula PhaaS.\r\n\r\nWhy does Sniper Dz provide PhaaS free of charge? Perhaps because Sniper Dz collects victim credentials stolen by phishers who use their platform to compensate for the cost of service.\r\n\r\nSniper Dz leaves a backdoor inside the phishing page for tracking and collecting stolen credentials as we describe later in this article. Providing this service for free allows Sniper Dz to register more phishers and obtain more stolen credentials. There are no free lunches.\r\nInfrastructure and Tactics\r\nThis section highlights key infrastructure and tactics employed by Sniper Dz. We describe evasion tactics such as hiding phishing content behind public proxy servers and obfuscating phishing content. We also show how Sniper Dz uses a centralized infrastructure to collect victim credentials stolen by other phishers and to track victims.\r\nHiding Phishing Content Behind Public Proxy Servers\r\nSniper Dz abuses a legitimate public proxy server (proxymesh[.]com) to hide its phishing content. Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply that the legitimate product is flawed or malicious.\r\n\r\nThe group behind Sniper Dz configures this proxy server to automatically load phishing content from its own server without direct communications. This technique can help Sniper Dz to protect its backend servers, since the victim\u2019s browser or a security crawler will see the proxy server as being responsible for loading the phishing payload.\r\n\r\nFigure 3 shows how Sniper Dz uses a public proxy server to hide requests to its web server (dev-cdn370[.]pantheonsite[.]io) hosting phishing content. The entry point is a disposable decoy phishing page that attackers could distribute to victims through emails or social media platforms. When a victim opens this page, it returns a script to automatically configure the proxy server.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136857\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 3. Workflow of hiding phishing content behind a public proxy server.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 4 shows part of the HTML content of a decoy phishing page that also includes this script to auto-configure the proxy server. The page includes an HTTP POST request form to proxymesh[.]com\/web\/index.php.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136859\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 4. An example of HTML code from a decoy webpage used to load phishing content from a proxy server.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis form mimics the request to load an input URL using a proxy provided by proxymesh[.]com. The JavaScript code snippet at the bottom assigns the \"url\" field of this form to the location of the phishing content, then it auto-submits the form to request content from the specified URL.\r\n\r\nEventually, the proxy server loads content from the web server hosting phishing content. As a result, the victim browser loads the phishing content through the proxy server without initiating a request to the web server hosting the phishing content. To detect such backend web servers hiding behind public proxy servers, defenders need to extract destination URLs by analyzing the scripts on the phishing pages.\r\n\r\nTo the best of our knowledge, we are the first to report this behavior of hiding backend server hosting phishing content behind public proxy servers.\r\nObfuscating Phishing Template Code\r\nThe contents of phishing template pages are heavily obfuscated. Figure 5 shows code from an example of a phishing page with obfuscated JavaScript to render the HTML script.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136861\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 5. Obfuscated JavaScript snippets of a phishing page.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFor example, it uses String.fromCharCode and unescape functions that we find attackers commonly use for obfuscating content. This obfuscation allows it to hide HTML code and critical infrastructure endpoints like the exfiltration URL.\r\nCentralized Infrastructure to Exfiltrate Credentials\r\nThese phishing pages exfiltrate credentials to a centralized infrastructure that Sniper Dz owns. Figure 6 shows a Google Chrome debugger console view of the exfiltration URL raviral[.]com\/k_fac.php where email and password are exfiltrated in parameters email and pass.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136863\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. Stolen credentials are exfiltrated to the endpoint raviral[.]com\/k_fac.php that Sniper Dz controls.[\/caption]By exfiltrating credentials to a centralized infrastructure it owns, Sniper Dz can harvest credentials from all of its clients' victims, including those who fell prey to its phishing templates hosted on other servers.\r\n\r\nFor phishers, stolen credentials of victims are displayed on the admin panel as shown in Figure 7. The admin panel shows the following information from the time the credentials were exfiltrated:\r\n\r\n \tUsername\r\n \tPassword\r\n \tTemplate name\r\n \tDate and time\r\n \tVictim's IP address and country\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136865\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Admin panel showing stolen credentials of victim along with additional information such as victim\u2019s IP address, country and time.[\/caption]\r\nTracking Victims and Phishing Templates\r\nSniper Dz tracks its victims by embedding custom JavaScript and analytics services. Figure 8 shows a custom tracking script for raviral[.]com\/host_style\/style\/js-track\/track.js included on a phishing page.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136867\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Example of a script included on a phishing page to track victims.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis script in turn loads a tracker from a legitimate analytics service. We surmise that these scripts allow Sniper Dz to track victims that visit both PhaaS links hosted on Sniper Dz infrastructure as well as offline phishing templates hosted by phishers on their own infrastructure.\r\nPhishing Attacks Using Sniper Dz\r\nSince last year, we have discovered over 140,000 phishing webpages associated with the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform. Figure 9 shows the discovery of these websites since July 2023.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136869\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 9. Discovery of live phishing pages authored by Sniper Dz in the past year.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nSniper Dz has remained active throughout this period. While its activity peaked in late 2023, we observed a surge in their activity starting in July 2024. Geographically, these phishing websites primarily target web users in the US.\r\n\r\nSniper Dz could have thousands of phishers as customers who are using its PhaaS platform to launch these phishing attacks. For example, Sniper Dz operates a Telegram channel t[.]me\/JokerDzV2 for customer support that had 7,156 subscribers in August 2024 as shown in Figure 10.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136871\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"500\"] Figure 10. Telegram channel t[.]me\/JokerDzV2 for Sniper Dz.[\/caption]In fact, one of the tutorial videos on this Telegram channel at\r\n\r\n \tt[.]me\/JokerDzV2\/19\r\n\r\nhad 72,600 views in August 2024 as shown in Figure 10. A large number of Telegram channel subscribers and video views indicate that a substantial number of prospective phishers could be using the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136873\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 11. Tutorial video to launch phishing attacks using Sniper Dz.[\/caption]\r\nAbusing Legitimate SaaS Platforms to Launch Phishing Attacks\r\nMost of the Sniper Dz phishing pages we have detected are hosted on legitimate SaaS platforms. Attackers commonly target legitimate SaaS platforms because the good reputation of legitimate domains can help threat actors evade detection from security crawlers. Blogspot was the most popular target among legitimate SaaS platforms.\r\n\r\nBlogspot appears to be more popular because the Sniper Dz admin panel offers an easy way to convert phishing templates to the Blogger format as shown below in Figure 12. Sniper Dz also provides a tutorial guide to enter converted phishing pages into Blogger for hosting on Blogspot.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136875\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"275\"] Figure 12. Sniper Dz admin panel offers a feature to convert a phishing page into a Blogger template.[\/caption]\r\nUsing Brand Names or Trends\/Events as Keywords in Hostnames\r\nSniper Dz authored phishing pages use keywords in hostnames that match popular brand names and trends or events, including sensitive political events. These deceptive hostnames can lure victims to these phishing pages and fall prey to phishing attacks.\r\nMalicious Redirects and PUP Distribution\r\nSniper Dz phishing pages can redirect users to other Sniper Dz owned websites like raviral[.]com after a victim is fooled into giving away login credentials. Attackers proliferate the raviral[.]com website with malicious advertisements and distribute PUA\/PUP-like, suspiciously labeled ad blockers and other browser extensions.\r\n\r\nDuring one of our test runs, the website triggered download of an installer for a rogue browser named Artificus as shown in Figure 13. Artificus is known for its intrusive behavior and we have also reported on it for being distributed by malicious advertisers.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136877\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 13. Webpage distributing a rogue browser named Artificus.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nThis article provides an in-depth investigation of an online PhaaS platform named Sniper Dz. Our study finds that a large number of phishers could be using this platform. We have discovered 140,000 phishing websites in the past year that we can attribute to this PhaaS.\r\n\r\nWe describe a unique technique employed by Sniper Dz to hide backend servers hosting phishing content behind public proxy servers. This technique allows Sniper Dz to protect its hosting infrastructure from security crawlers. Sniper Dz also uses more commonly known techniques to evade detections such as obfuscating phishing content and abusing legitimate SaaS platforms to host phishing pages.\r\n\r\nWe also found that Sniper Dz phishing pages exfiltrate victim credentials and track them through a centralized infrastructure. This could be helping Sniper Dz collect victim credentials stolen by phishers who use their PhaaS platform.\r\n\r\nWe hope this blog helps our readers to stay protected from the harmful effects of this phishing campaign. Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through our Next-Generation Firewall's Advanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security subscriptions.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nAcknowledgments\r\nWe\u2019d like to thank the entire Unit 42 team for supporting us with this post. Special thanks to Bradley Duncan, Lysa Myers and Adnan Ahmed for their invaluable input on this blog.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nSniper Dz PhaaS Platform:\r\n\r\n \tSniperdz[.]com\r\n\r\nPhysical location of phishing webpages concealed using proxy servers:\r\n\r\n \tdev-cdn370.pantheonsite.io\r\n\r\nCentralized exfiltration endpoint:\r\n\r\n \traviral[.]com\/k_fac.php\r\n\r\nEmbedded tracker script:\r\n\r\n \traviral[.]com\/host_style\/style\/js-track\/track.js\r\n\r\nTelegram support channel:\r\n\r\n \tt[.]me\/JokerDzV2\r\n\r\nSniper Dz platform tutorial video:\r\n\r\n \tt[.]me\/JokerDzV2\/19\r\n\r\nRedirection to Sniper Dz-owned websites:\r\n\r\n \traviral[.]com\r\n\r\nExamples of phishing websites generated using Sniper Dz:\r\n\r\n \t6627c220b5daa507c6cca1c5--votedme[.]netlify.app\r\n \tautomaticgiveaway[.]000webhostapp[.]com\r\n \tClimbing-green-botany[.]glitch[.]me\r\n \tfacebookbusiness0078[.]blogspot.be\r\n \tfree-fire-reward-garena-bd-nepazl[.]epizy[.]com\r\n \tfreefirefff[.]github[.]io\r\n \tff-rewards-redeem-codes-org[.]github.io\r\n \tinstagram-cutequeen57[.]netlify.app\r\n \tpubg-tournament-official[.]github.io\/free-fire-reedeem-code\r\n \tv0tingsystem[.]github[.]io\r\n\r\nExamples of Sniper Dz Live phishing pages hosted on their own infrastructure:\r\n\r\n \tpro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com\/about\/z1to.html?u=ff-insta\/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]\r\n \tpro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com\/about\/z2to.html?u=ff-reward\/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]\r\n \tpro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com\/about\/z2to.html?u=ff-spiner\/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]\r\n \tpro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com\/about\/z1to.html?u=eb-log\/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]\r\n \tpro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com\/about\/z1to.html?u=s-mobi\/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]\r\n\r\nLegitimate public proxy service abused to hide phishing content:\r\n\r\n \tproxymesh[.]com\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/09\/10_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Shehroze Farooqi"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Howard Tong"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Alex Starov"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' <style id='co-authors-plus-coauthors-style-inline-css'>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-136850 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/10_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/business-email-compromise/" role="link" title="Business Email Compromise" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics:hero:breadcrumb:Business Email Compromise">Business Email Compromise</a></li> </ul>

                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phishing-platform-sniper-dz-unique-tactics:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>

              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-136850-_x88yhhoxz4ph"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>We have been monitoring a widely popular phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform named Sniper Dz that primarily targets popular social media platforms and online services. A large number of phishers could be using this platform to launch phishing attacks, since the group behind this kit has thousands of subscribers on its Telegram channel. Our research revealed over 140,000 phishing websites associated with the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform over the past year.</p>
<p>For prospective phishers, Sniper Dz offers an online admin panel with a catalog of phishing pages. Phishers can either host these phishing pages on Sniper Dz-owned infrastructure or download Sniper Dz phishing templates to host on their own servers. Surprisingly, Sniper Dz PhaaS offers these services free of charge to phishers – perhaps because Sniper Dz also collects victim credentials stolen by phishers who use the platform to compensate for the cost of service.</p>
<p>Sniper Dz uses a unique approach of hiding phishing content behind a public proxy server to launch live phishing attacks. The criminals behind this platform auto-setup the proxy server to load phishing content that is hosted on their server. We believe this approach could be useful in protecting their infrastructure from detection.</p>
<p>Criminals using Sniper Dz often abuse legitimate software-as-a-service (SaaS) platforms to host phishing websites. When establishing their infrastructure, these phishers include popular brand names, trends and even sensitive topics as keywords to lure victims into opening and using their phishing pages. After stealing credentials from a victim, this infrastructure can redirect the victim to malicious advertisements including distribution of potentially unwanted applications or programs (PUA or PUP) like rogue browser installers.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a>'s <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> subscriptions.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 24px;">
<thead>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 35%; height: 24px;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%; height: 24px;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing-kit/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Phishing Kit</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/business-email-compromise/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Business Email Compromise (BEC)</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_x8ml1fk7kck6"></a><strong>Sniper Dz PhaaS Platform</strong></h2>
<p>Sniper Dz is a PhaaS platform that allows prospective phishers to launch phishing attacks. Sniper Dz offers an admin panel to generate phishing pages.</p>
<p>Gaining access to this admin panel requires creating an account with an email address. Once users (or phishers) create an account, they can access a wide variety of phishing pages targeting popular brands.</p>
<p>Sniper Dz provides two different methods to launch live phishing attacks.</p>
<ol>
<li>Phishing pages hosted on Sniper Dz infrastructure</li>
<li>Downloadable phishing templates to host on one's own infrastructure</li>
</ol>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_jliecyu3r6yl"></a><strong>Phishing Pages Hosted on Sniper Dz Infrastructure</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz can host phishing pages on its own infrastructure and provide customized links pointed to those pages. Figure 1 shows the Sniper Dz admin panel page that shares temporary links pointing to live phishing pages for different brands customized for the registered user. In this way, a prospective phisher does not have to set up a web server to host phishing websites and use Sniper Dz’s infrastructure to launch phishing attacks.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136853" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136853" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136853" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1.png" alt="Screenshot of the Sniper Dz admin panel. The Page tab is open and there is also a Links tab. The main focus is on screenshots of multiple websites with some information redacted. There are recommended links that can be copied and pasted. " width="900" height="733" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1-540x440.png 540w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1-859x700.png 859w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1-768x626.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-744234-136850-1-1536x1252.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136853" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Sniper Dz admin panel to launch phishing attacks on Sniper Dz-hosted infrastructure.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Content for these live phishing pages is hidden behind proxy servers to prevent detection, which we will explain in more detail later in this article.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_msg4gl6drvzz"></a><strong>Downloadable Phishing Templates</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz also enables phishers to download phishing page templates offline as HTML files and host them on their own servers. Figure 2 shows the page to download phishing templates of numerous target brands.  Prospective phishers can simply pick a target brand, download the associated phishing page, and deploy it on their own servers.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136855" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136855" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136855" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2.png" alt="Screenshot of Sniper Dz website interface displaying various options for template page setups, customizable buttons for data management, and different user account status panels, all depicted in a dark mode theme." width="900" height="496" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2-786x433.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2-1270x700.png 1270w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2-768x423.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-749977-136850-2-1536x847.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136855" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. List of downloadable phishing template pages from the Sniper Dz site.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_nexnqha6xqta"></a><strong>Is This Really a Free-of-Charge PhaaS Platform?</strong></h3>
<p>Surprisingly, Sniper Dz offers both phishing attack options free of charge. Normally, PhaaS platforms and phishing kit authors charge money. Setting up a live phishing attack using PhaaS platforms can cost hundreds of dollars in monthly subscription fees, as seen with the <a href="https://securityintelligence.com/articles/phishing-as-a-service-makes-us-jittery/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Caffeine PhaaS</a> or the <a href="https://www.darkreading.com/endpoint-security/-darcula-phishing-as-a-service-operation-bleeds-victims-worldwide" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Darcula PhaaS.</a></p>
<p>Why does Sniper Dz provide PhaaS free of charge? Perhaps because Sniper Dz collects victim credentials stolen by phishers who use their platform to compensate for the cost of service.</p>
<p>Sniper Dz leaves a backdoor inside the phishing page for tracking and collecting stolen credentials as we describe later in this article. Providing this service for free allows Sniper Dz to register more phishers and obtain more stolen credentials. There are no free lunches.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_4lt92rr5muov"></a><strong>Infrastructure and Tactics</strong></h2>
<p>This section highlights key infrastructure and tactics employed by Sniper Dz. We describe evasion tactics such as hiding phishing content behind public proxy servers and obfuscating phishing content. We also show how Sniper Dz uses a centralized infrastructure to collect victim credentials stolen by other phishers and to track victims.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_6wf3yzezupnc"></a><strong>Hiding Phishing Content Behind Public Proxy Servers</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz abuses a legitimate public proxy server (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">proxymesh[.]com</span>) to hide its phishing content. Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply that the legitimate product is flawed or malicious.</p>
<p>The group behind Sniper Dz configures this proxy server to automatically load phishing content from its own server without direct communications. This technique can help Sniper Dz to protect its backend servers, since the victim’s browser or a security crawler will see the proxy server as being responsible for loading the phishing payload.</p>
<p>Figure 3 shows how Sniper Dz uses a public proxy server to hide requests to its web server (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dev-cdn370[.]pantheonsite[.]io</span>) hosting phishing content. The entry point is a disposable decoy phishing page that attackers could distribute to victims through emails or social media platforms. When a victim opens this page, it returns a script to automatically configure the proxy server.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136857" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136857" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136857" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3.png" alt="Flowchart explaining a phishing attack via a proxy server setup, involving a decoy page, public server, and a web server hosting phishing content. Major steps include victim opening phishing webpage, proxy server configuration, and delivery of phishing content. Logo of Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 appear at the bottom." width="700" height="327" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3-1496x700.png 1496w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3-768x359.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-754830-136850-3-1536x719.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136857" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Workflow of hiding phishing content behind a public proxy server.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 4 shows part of the HTML content of a decoy phishing page that also includes this script to auto-configure the proxy server. The page includes an HTTP POST request form to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">proxymesh[.]com/web/index.php</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136859" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136859" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136859" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4.png" alt="Screenshot of HTML and JavaScript code related to a form element on the 'proxymesh.com' website. The code includes functions for encoding URLs and adding event listeners to a form. Two sections are highlighted in red boxes. " width="700" height="514" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4-599x440.png 599w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4-953x700.png 953w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4-768x564.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-758477-136850-4-1536x1128.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136859" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. An example of HTML code from a decoy webpage used to load phishing content from a proxy server.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This form mimics the request to load an input URL using a proxy provided by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">proxymesh[.]com</span>. The JavaScript code snippet at the bottom assigns the "<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">url</span>" field of this form to the location of the phishing content, then it auto-submits the form to request content from the specified URL.</p>
<p>Eventually, the proxy server loads content from the web server hosting phishing content. As a result, the victim browser loads the phishing content through the proxy server without initiating a request to the web server hosting the phishing content. To detect such backend web servers hiding behind public proxy servers, defenders need to extract destination URLs by analyzing the scripts on the phishing pages.</p>
<p>To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to report this behavior of hiding backend server hosting phishing content behind public proxy servers.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_5dvp1w3ghcyy"></a><strong>Obfuscating Phishing Template Code</strong></h3>
<p>The contents of phishing template pages are heavily obfuscated. Figure 5 shows code from an example of a phishing page with obfuscated JavaScript to render the HTML script.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136861" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136861" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136861" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code written in JavaScript displayed in a text editor, with various functions and strings visible. At the bottom, two sections are highlighted within red boxes." width="700" height="440" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5.png 1872w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5-699x440.png 699w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5-1112x700.png 1112w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5-768x483.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-762496-136850-5-1536x967.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136861" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Obfuscated JavaScript snippets of a phishing page.</figcaption></figure>
<p>For example, it uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">String.fromCharCode</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unescape</span> functions that we find attackers commonly use for obfuscating content. This obfuscation allows it to hide HTML code and critical infrastructure endpoints like the exfiltration URL.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_ckwg6twekyw3"></a><strong>Centralized Infrastructure to Exfiltrate Credentials</strong></h3>
<p>These phishing pages exfiltrate credentials to a centralized infrastructure that Sniper Dz owns. Figure 6 shows a Google Chrome debugger console view of the exfiltration URL <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com/k_fac.php</span> where email and password are exfiltrated in parameters email and pass.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_136863" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136863" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136863" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6.png" alt="Screenshot of response headers, request headers, and form data for a Netflix login page, highlighting the fields for email and password." width="900" height="600" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6-660x440.png 660w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6-1049x700.png 1049w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6-768x512.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-767099-136850-6-1536x1025.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136863" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Stolen credentials are exfiltrated to the endpoint <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com/k_fac.php</span> that Sniper Dz controls.</figcaption></figure>By exfiltrating credentials to a centralized infrastructure it owns, Sniper Dz can harvest credentials from all of its clients' victims, including those who fell prey to its phishing templates hosted on other servers.</p>
<p>For phishers, stolen credentials of victims are displayed on the admin panel as shown in Figure 7. The admin panel shows the following information from the time the credentials were exfiltrated:</p>
<ul>
<li>Username</li>
<li>Password</li>
<li>Template name</li>
<li>Date and time</li>
<li>Victim's IP address and country</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_136865" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136865" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136865" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7.png" alt="A screenshot showing a web browser interface for &quot;sniperdz.com&quot; titled 'VICTIMS'. The screen displays a table with columns such as Id, Scama name, User name and more. Two entries are visible from the United States, and the interface includes navigation buttons and functionality for searching, downloading, and removing entries. There are more options and tools in the left sidebar." width="900" height="589" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7-672x440.png 672w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7-1070x700.png 1070w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7-768x503.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-773078-136850-7-1536x1005.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136865" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Admin panel showing stolen credentials of victim along with additional information such as victim’s IP address, country and time.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_9sktlrects67"></a><strong>Tracking Victims and Phishing Templates</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz tracks its victims by embedding custom JavaScript and analytics services. Figure 8 shows a custom tracking script for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com/host_style/style/js-track/track.js</span> included on a phishing page.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136867" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136867" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136867" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8.png" alt="A screenshot displaying a segment of HTML code with references to Netflix and other generic script elements. The last line has a section highlighted by a red box." width="900" height="397" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8.png 1738w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8-786x346.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8-1588x700.png 1588w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8-768x338.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-777725-136850-8-1536x677.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136867" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Example of a script included on a phishing page to track victims.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This script in turn loads a tracker from a legitimate analytics service. We surmise that these scripts allow Sniper Dz to track victims that visit both PhaaS links hosted on Sniper Dz infrastructure as well as offline phishing templates hosted by phishers on their own infrastructure.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_mdgtz8i0qf2b"></a><strong>Phishing Attacks Using Sniper Dz</strong></h2>
<p>Since last year, we have discovered over 140,000 phishing webpages associated with the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform. Figure 9 shows the discovery of these websites since July 2023.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136869" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136869" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136869" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1.png" alt="Line graph displaying fluctuations in the number of URLs. The y-axis is on a logarithmic scale from 1 to 10,000, and the x-axis shows dates from July 1, 2023, to July 1, 2024. Logo of Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42." width="900" height="367" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1-786x320.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1-1719x700.png 1719w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1-768x313.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1-1536x626.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136869" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Discovery of live phishing pages authored by Sniper Dz in the past year.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Sniper Dz has remained active throughout this period. While its activity peaked in late 2023, we observed a surge in their activity starting in July 2024. Geographically, these phishing websites primarily target web users in the US.</p>
<p>Sniper Dz could have thousands of phishers as customers who are using its PhaaS platform to launch these phishing attacks. For example, Sniper Dz operates a Telegram channel <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t[.]me/JokerDzV2</span> for customer support that had 7,156 subscribers in August 2024 as shown in Figure 10.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_136871" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136871" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136871" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-786658-136850-10.png" alt="Promotional image for Telegram channel &quot;Sniper Dz&quot; which features a logo with a stylized sniper image and the text &quot;sniperdz.com&quot;. The channel has 7 followers. There is a &quot;View in Telegram&quot; button and a &quot;Download&quot; button at the top." width="500" height="525" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-786658-136850-10.png 1012w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-786658-136850-10-419x440.png 419w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-786658-136850-10-667x700.png 667w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-786658-136850-10-768x806.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136871" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Telegram channel <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t[.]me/JokerDzV2</span> for Sniper Dz.</figcaption></figure>In fact, one of the tutorial videos on this Telegram channel at</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t[.]me/JokerDzV2/19</span></li>
</ul>
<p>had 72,600 views in August 2024 as shown in Figure 10. A large number of Telegram channel subscribers and video views indicate that a substantial number of prospective phishers could be using the Sniper Dz PhaaS platform.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136873" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136873" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136873" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-790855-136850-11.png" alt="Social media post from &quot;Sniper Dz&quot; displaying an error message saying &quot;Media is too big&quot; with a button labeled &quot;VIEW IN TELEGRAM&quot;. Includes a link to Telegram, a view count, and a timestamp indicating November 10, 2020, at 02:29." width="600" height="427" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-790855-136850-11.png 1124w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-790855-136850-11-618x440.png 618w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-790855-136850-11-984x700.png 984w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-790855-136850-11-768x547.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136873" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Tutorial video to launch phishing attacks using Sniper Dz.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_ovvamxkh4zro"></a><strong>Abusing Legitimate SaaS Platforms to Launch Phishing Attacks</strong></h3>
<p>Most of the Sniper Dz phishing pages we have detected are hosted on legitimate SaaS platforms. <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/platform-abuse-phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Attackers commonly target legitimate SaaS platforms</a> because the good reputation of legitimate domains can help threat actors evade detection from security crawlers. Blogspot was the most popular target among legitimate SaaS platforms.</p>
<p>Blogspot appears to be more popular because the Sniper Dz admin panel offers an easy way to convert phishing templates to the Blogger format as shown below in Figure 12. Sniper Dz also provides a tutorial guide to enter converted phishing pages into Blogger for hosting on Blogspot.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136875" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136875" style="width: 275px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136875" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-794249-136850-12.png" alt="Screenshot of a software application menu, labeled &quot;SNIPERDZ&quot; at the top. The menu includes icons and text for various options including Home, Victims, Scams, Change Password, Scam Encrypter, Convert To Blogger, and Tutorials. The Convert To Blogger option is highlighted with an XML tag indicating its format, and some options have additional labels like 'Offline', 'Beta', and 'Pro'." width="275" height="571" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-794249-136850-12.png 482w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-794249-136850-12-212x440.png 212w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-794249-136850-12-337x700.png 337w" sizes="(max-width: 275px) 100vw, 275px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136875" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Sniper Dz admin panel offers a feature to convert a phishing page into a Blogger template.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_ihcwa9a53b0y"></a><strong>Using Brand Names or Trends/Events as Keywords in Hostnames</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz authored phishing pages use keywords in hostnames that match popular brand names and trends or events, including sensitive political events. These deceptive hostnames can lure victims to these phishing pages and fall prey to phishing attacks.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136850-_7f8u8myr9vbo"></a><strong>Malicious Redirects and PUP Distribution</strong></h3>
<p>Sniper Dz phishing pages can redirect users to other Sniper Dz owned websites like <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com</span> after a victim is fooled into giving away login credentials. Attackers proliferate the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com</span> website with malicious advertisements and distribute PUA/PUP-like, suspiciously labeled ad blockers and other browser extensions.</p>
<p>During one of our test runs, the website triggered download of an installer for a rogue browser named Artificus as shown in Figure 13. Artificus is known for its intrusive behavior and we have also <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/apateweb-scareware-pup-delivery-campaign/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reported on it for being distributed by malicious advertisers</a>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136877" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136877" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136877" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13.png" alt="Download instructions for Artifactus software displayed on a webpage. Two options are shown: &quot;Download Now&quot; to start the download and &quot;Run the Setup&quot; for installation instructions." width="900" height="512" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13-773x440.png 773w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13-1230x700.png 1230w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13-768x437.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-796802-136850-13-1536x875.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136877" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Webpage distributing a rogue browser named Artificus.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_stiwxy613j0a"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>This article provides an in-depth investigation of an online PhaaS platform named Sniper Dz. Our study finds that a large number of phishers could be using this platform. We have discovered 140,000 phishing websites in the past year that we can attribute to this PhaaS.</p>
<p>We describe a unique technique employed by Sniper Dz to hide backend servers hosting phishing content behind public proxy servers. This technique allows Sniper Dz to protect its hosting infrastructure from security crawlers. Sniper Dz also uses more commonly known techniques to evade detections such as obfuscating phishing content and abusing legitimate SaaS platforms to host phishing pages.</p>
<p>We also found that Sniper Dz phishing pages exfiltrate victim credentials and track them through a centralized infrastructure. This could be helping Sniper Dz collect victim credentials stolen by phishers who use their PhaaS platform.</p>
<p>We hope this blog helps our readers to stay protected from the harmful effects of this phishing campaign. Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a>'s <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> subscriptions.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_mjjurvl0o0y2"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>
<p>We’d like to thank the entire Unit 42 team for supporting us with this post. Special thanks to Bradley Duncan, Lysa Myers and Adnan Ahmed for their invaluable input on this blog.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136850-_dvj6wbt3kg4m"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<p>Sniper Dz PhaaS Platform:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sniperdz[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Physical location of phishing webpages concealed using proxy servers:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dev-cdn370.pantheonsite.io</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Centralized exfiltration endpoint:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com/k_fac.php</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Embedded tracker script:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com/host_style/style/js-track/track.js</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Telegram support channel:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t[.]me/JokerDzV2</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Sniper Dz platform tutorial video:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t[.]me/JokerDzV2/19</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Redirection to Sniper Dz-owned websites:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">raviral[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of phishing websites generated using Sniper Dz:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6627c220b5daa507c6cca1c5--votedme[.]netlify.app</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">automaticgiveaway[.]000webhostapp[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Climbing-green-botany[.]glitch[.]me</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">facebookbusiness0078[.]blogspot.be</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">free-fire-reward-garena-bd-nepazl[.]epizy[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">freefirefff[.]github[.]io</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ff-rewards-redeem-codes-org[.]github.io</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">instagram-cutequeen57[.]netlify.app</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pubg-tournament-official[.]github.io/free-fire-reedeem-code</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">v0tingsystem[.]github[.]io</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of Sniper Dz Live phishing pages hosted on their own infrastructure:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com/about/z1to.html?u=ff-insta/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com/about/z2to.html?u=ff-reward/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com/about/z2to.html?u=ff-spiner/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com/about/z1to.html?u=eb-log/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro[.]riccardomalisano[.]com/about/z1to.html?u=s-mobi/?i=[Redacted_For_Anonymity]</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Legitimate public proxy service abused to hide phishing content:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">proxymesh[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
      
              </div>

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Business Email Compromise Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                              <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/03_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of phishing campaigns delivered through refresh HTTP response headers.
